Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Leaving home: genetic, endocrine, and behavioral correlates of dispersal in monogamous monkeys

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In some primate species, it is common for individuals to leave the group in which they were born to join a different group (dispersal), but the evolutionary reasons dispersal are not completely understood. Primates exhibit high levels of inter- and intra-specific variation in dispersal, and there are costs associated with unfamiliar locations and/or aggressive competitors. Many models attempting to explain the evolution of dispersal have proposed a tight link among dispersal patterns, mating systems, and life history traits. Developing a better understanding of how social and mating systems influence and are influenced by dispersal patterns is essential for understanding the evolution of social and mating systems in primates, including humans. This project will study primate dispersal in a socially monogamous monkey species using genetic and hormone data collected non-invasively. This research is part of the Owl Monkey Project (OMP), a long-term initiative to promote research, conservation, and education in the Argentinean Chaco. Broader impacts include training of a female graduate student and undergraduate students in a STEM field, and support of international collaborations between the US and Argentina.

In this dissertation project, the co-PI will examine genetic, endocrine, and behavioral correlates of dispersal in free-ranging, socially monogamous owl monkeys of the Argentinean Chaco. The project will explore dispersal at the level of the community by genetically sampling individuals, and at the level of the social group by examining hormones and behavior in subadult males and females. Specifically, it will utilize genotype data from ~250 owl monkeys, behavioral data from 22 predispersing subadults, and steroid hormone data from ~1000 fecal samples to address current debates over the relationships between mating system and dispersal by evaluating inbreeding and competition avoidance hypotheses. These genetic, behavioral, and hormonal data will also be used to evaluate the costs and benefits of delaying dispersal in groups where a variable number of close kin may be present. Genetic data from this project also have strong potential to elucidate how a bisexually dispersing species may utilize differences in the average distance dispersed by each sex to avoid potential costs of inbreeding. The unique multi-level approach and integrative nature of this study of natal dispersal in a socially monogamous species has potential to illuminate the origins of dispersal and mating patterns in pair-bonded primates, including humans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Leaving a natal group confronts dispersing individuals with costs, yet natal dispersal by at least some individuals is a trait common to all primates. Developing a better understanding of how social and mating systems influence and are influenced by dispersal patterns is essential if we are to understand the evolution of social and mating systems in primates, including humans. This research, carried out by co-PI Corley as part of her PhD dissertation, sought to advance our understanding of primate dispersal by examining demographic, endocrine, and behavioral correlates of natal dispersal in free-ranging, socially monogamous owl monkeys (Aotus azarae) of the Argentinean Chaco.

This research utilized a more holistic approach than many previous studies of dispersal, and aims to provide a template for a more integrative method of examining dispersal patterns. Evolutionary theory has long recognized that addressing different types of questions, or “levels” of explanation, is essential for developing a comprehensive understanding of a behavioral trait. Together, the different aspects of dispersal investigated in this project provide insight into both proximate and ultimate causes for dispersal patterns in a monogamous primate. Specifically, drawing from 20 years of demographic data, this project explored natal dispersal at the level of the community by examining how dispersal patterns were linked to seasonality and changes in group composition. At the level of the group, it utilized 14 years of behavioral focal data to examine how social behavior among group members may function to regulate offspring dispersal. Finally, using fecal samples, it assessed hormone levels in offspring and examined how hormone concentrations and the timing of sexual maturity may be associated with individuals’ dispersal decisions.

Results suggest that owl monkeys have evolved relatively flexible dispersal strategies. Both sexes of owl monkeys disperse, on average, at around three years of age, but offspring may leave their natal groups any time between the ages of two and five. The timing of dispersal is not strongly linked to group size, infant births, or seasons associated with high food competition. Instead, our results suggest that owl monkeys most often disperse in periods of high resource abundance, perhaps in order to mitigate the costs of ranging solitarily after dispersing. Replacements of adults also appear to influence the timing of dispersal. On average, subadults remained in their natal groups more than twice as long after the replacement of the opposite sex adult than after the same sex adult was replaced. Our results suggest that, while dispersals are somewhat seasonal, dispersal may occur at any time of the year in cases where changes in group composition increases the potential risk of inbreeding and reduces the potential nepotistic benefits individuals could receive by remaining in their natal group with kin.

This study also found that behavior, particularly aggression, among group members may function to regulate natal dispersal. Both male and female offspring experience similar rates of aggression from adults in their natal groups. Older offspring (i.e. subadults) are involved in aggressive events more often than younger offspring (i.e. infants and juveniles), and also receive more aggression from adults than do younger offspring. Subadults also experience more aggression from adults in the period just prior to dispersing, which suggests that aggression may be a mechanism that adults utilize to encourage offspring to disperse.

Female owl monkeys’ hormone profiles indicated that they typically experience the onset of sexual maturity while they are still in their natal group, prior to dispersing. In contrast, males did not show increased androgen levels, which would have been indicative of reproductive maturity, until after dispersing from their natal group. This suggests that females may disperse to avoid mating competition with adults in their natal group, particularly if one of their parents has been replaced by an unrelated adult.

The results of this multi-faceted study provide complementary insights and will lead to a more complete understanding of dispersal behavior in not only owl monkeys, but other monogamous taxa as well.

Broader Impacts: This research was conducted as part of the Owl Monkey Project (OMP), which collaborates with Fundación E.C.O. to promote research, conservation, and education in the Argentinean Chaco. This project has generated collaborations between researchers in the US and Argentina, which have allowed the results of this project to be translated and shared with members of the local community in Formosa, Argentina through public talks and workshops. This project has also contributed substantially to the education and training of graduate students, including co-PI Corley, and has enabled undergraduate students to gain experience in conducting scientific research in both the laboratory and the field. Finally, the project has expanded the OMP Database, an NSF-funded resource available for collaborative research, and has produced biological samples and laboratory protocols that can be utilized in additional scientific research.
